title: Evidence of Flowing Water Discovered on Mars: NASA
text:
28 Sep 2015 09:37 PM EST 
-by Anthony Bell, Contributing Writer; Image: Streaks from flowing water on Mars (Image Source: NASA) 
NASA announced on Monday morning that they have discovered water that still sometimes flows on the surface of Mars, giving more hope in the potential for life on our neighbor planet. 
The discovery did not reveal evidence of current or even previous life on the planet, but it has given scientists hope that living microbes could still be found. 
“There is liquid water today on the surface of Mars,” Michael Meyer, lead scientist on NASA’s Mars exploration program, said, according to the Guardian . “Because of this, we suspect that it is at least possible to have a habitable environment today.” 
“Mars is not the dry, arid planet that we thought of in the past,” added NASA’s Jim Green. “Liquid water has been found on Mars.” 
“The existence of liquid water, even if it is super salty briny water, gives the possibility that if there's life on Mars, that we have a way to describe how it might survive,” John Grunsfeld, associate administrator for the Science Mission Directorate at NASA, explained, CNN notes . 
Researchers discovered stains left over from liquid flowing water down cliffs and crater walls in the summer, which increases the chance of finding life. The water leaves long, dark stains on the terrain that can reach hundreds of meters downhill in warmer months, The Guardian reports . The water then dries up in autumn when surface temperatures fall. 
Georgia Tech doctoral student Lujendra Ojha first discovered the streaks in 2011 while an undergraduate student at the University of Arizona. Ojha explained that the streaks “absorb light at specific wavelengths associated with chemicals known to pull water from the Martian atmosphere in a process known as deliquescence,” according to the Guardian. Those chemicals not only help the water continue to be liquid at lower temperatures but also help keep it from boiling away in the thin air. 
Even early Mars missions revealed signs of water. Pictures from the 1970s showed a surface covered in dried-up rivers and plains that were once underwater. This year, the agency also provided evidence of an ocean that may have covered half of the planet’s northern hemisphere. 
Images taken from this recent orbit show cliffs, as well as steep walls of valleys and craters, covered in streaks from the summer flows. Scientists are not certain where the water comes from, though they hypothesize that it could rise up from underground ice or salty aquifers, or condense out of the atmosphere. The next round of research will delve into just what causes the mysterious phenomenon, Meyer said. 
The current findings will be included in new paper that is to be presented this week at the European Planetary Science Congress in France.
